results.title: Reflections in a golden eye
results.creator_credit: John Huston, Ray Stark and Warner Bros Pictures
results.brief_description: An edgy drama based on a novel by Carson McCullers this feature focuses on complicated relationships. The story is set on a Southern American Army Base in 1948 and is a complex web of sexual repression, military discipline and extra-marital affairs. Major Penderton (Marlon Brando) hides his homosexual tendencies behind strict discipline while his frustrated wife (Elizabeth Taylor) has an affair with a Lt. Colonel (Brian Keith). To make things more complicated the Lt. Colonel’s wife is also having an affair with her houseboy. Then there is Private Williams (Robert Foster) who likes naked horse riding. The repressed and obsessive Major Penderton has strong feelings of mixed jealousy when the young Private shows interest in his wife rather than him. This story of bad marriages and military life is both bleak and obsessive. The characters are living in a self imposed prison which they can not escape. This is a tense and compelling drama although criticized for its average screenplay.

results.creator_credit_for_label: Anatole Litvak, Buddy Adler and Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation
results.description: Classic film from the play by Marcelle Maurette, adapted by Guy Bolton and screenplay by Arthur Laurents. The story is based on a factual account of the mystery that surrounded the Russian princess Anastasia, youngest daughter of Tzar Nicholas II, who along with her family was imprisoned and shot after the 1917 revolution. Or was she shot? Did Anastasia in fact live on? The scene is Paris in 1928 during the time of Russian Easter. A destitute and suicidal woman suffering from amnesia who remarkably resembles Princess Anastasia (Ingrid Bergman) is rescued by exiled Russian General Bounine (Yul Brynner). The suave, but forceful General, conspires to pass this woman off as the long-lost daughter of the Tzar for the sole purpose of benefiting from the Princess’s ten million pound inheritance. But there are many who remain sceptical, not least of all the Russian Grand Duchess (Helen Hayes), grandmother of the real Anastasia. An intriguing plot played out superbly by Bergman and Brynner but also made all the more intriguing following Bergman’s own Hollywood comeback from exile in Europe after her affair with Italian director, Roberto Rossellini. (Awards: Academy Awards, 1957, Ingrid Bergman for Best Actress in a Leading Role; Golden Globes, 1957, Ingrid Bergman for Best Motion Picture Actress - Drama)

results.title: The Man on the flying trapeze
results.creator_credit: Clyde Bruckman, Paramount Pictures and William Le Baron
results.brief_description: W.C. Fields plays Ambrose Wolfinger who is a very henpecked family man. Given no respect from his overbearing relatives including a picky mother-in-law, lazy brother-in-law and his bossy and nagging wife, Ambrose has a constant battle as everything seeming to be against him. His saving only grace is his daughter from a previous marriage and the workplace where he has a mild respect for his amazing memory. What happens when he wants to have an afternoon off to see a wrestling match is a series of mishaps where he finds himself out of a job and exiled by his family. This comedy of errors is an entertaining display of the art of Fields as a comedian. “The Man on the Flying Trapeze” is made up of a collection of short gags, almost short films in themselves, which make up the whole compelling feature. It is a fine farce of married life, in-laws and dysfunctional relationships where nothing ever goes right but is always funny. Cast also includes Mary Brian, Kathleen Howard and Lucien Littlefield.

results.title: Playing for time
results.creator_credit: Daniel Mann, Linda Yellen and Syzygy Productions
results.brief_description: Based on the memoirs of Fania Fenelon in her book The Musicians of Auschwitz and written for television by Arthur Miller, this feature length program stars Vanessa Redgrave in the role of Fenelon, a French-Jewish cabaret singer who was working in Paris at the time of the Nazi invasion and who was eventually shipped off to the Nazi death camp in Auschwitz in 1944. Fenelon, along with several other women musicians, is forced to perform for the condemned inmates facing the gas chamber in exchange for her own survival. As long as the group keep performing so their lives are spared and no more aware of this is their leader Alma Rose (Jane Alexander). Conflict and tension increases between these two women as each explores their soul and conscience in this inhumane and degrading struggle for life. For the viewer it raises many issues of the human condition and what price survival but perhaps more controversial is the fact that Vanessa Redgrave is well-known for her anti-Zionist stance, causing wide opposition by many including the real-life Fenelon, to Redgrave’s appearance in the film. However Redgrave puts in a magnificent performance winning her an Emmy Award, along with Emmy Awards for scriptwriter Arthur Miller, supporting actress Jane Alexander, and Oustanding Dramatic Special Award for the film itself. Cast also includes Maud Adams, Shirley Knight, Marisa Berenson, Robin Bartlett, Mady Kaplan. A compelling and poignant story.

results.title: A Bill of divorcement. Ruby Gentry
results.creator_credit: George Cukor, King Vidor, David O. Selznick, Joseph Bernhard, Bernhard-Vidor Productions and RKO Radio Pictures
results.brief_description: A Bill of divorcement: Katharine Hepburn’s debut in what was to be the first film in a long association with director George Cukor. Hillary Fairfield (John Barrymore), shellshocked during World War One, escapes from the asylum on the day his ex-wife is to remarry. Unable to adjust, he must also confront his now grown-up daughter Sydney (katharine Hepburn). Facing reality, he finally accepts his wife’s determination to marry a sane, healthy man, but does not know of the impending sacrifice his daughter is to make. Sydney knows that the streak of madness in her father is inherited, not war-induced and, fearful of passing it on to her children, she cancels her marriage in order to care for her father. Cast also includes Billie Burke and David Manners. Ruby Gentry: Jennifer Jones stars as Ruby, a young southern woman from a poor white-trash family determined to improve her lot in life by marrying into wealth even though she is romantically involved with Boake Tackman (Charlton Heston) who too is from the “wrong” side of the tracks. So when successful businessman Jim Gentry (Karl Malden) finds himself totally in love with Ruby and insists on making her his wife, Ruby, of course, cannot resist this fortuitous offer. However, for Gentry it will turn out to be a most unfortunate decision with dire consequences. Cast also includes Tom Tully and James Anderson.

results.title: Son of Lassie
results.creator_credit: S. Sylvan Simon, Samuel Marx and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer
results.brief_description: Introduced by Bill Collins, “Son of Lassie” is a sequel to “Lassie come home”, based on some characters from the book “Lassie come home” by Eric Knight. It is set during World War II and tells the story of adventure and loyalty between man and dog - Ken (Peter Lawford) and Laddie, son of everyone’s favourite collie, Lassie. A classic family favourite with a cast including Donald Crisp, June Lockhart, Nigel Bruce.

results.title: Abe Lincoln in Illinois
results.creator_credit: John Cromwell, Max Gordon and RKO Radio Pictures
results.brief_description: Adapted from the Pulitzer Prize-winning play by American author and playwright, Robert E. Sherwood, this film version captures the essence and fervour of one of America’s most memorable periods in its founding history. It takes a biographical slice of time out of Abraham Lincoln’s (Raymond Massey) life beginning with his early adult years as a woodsman, to his courtships first with Ann Rutledge (Mary Howard) and then with Mary Todd (Ruth Gordon), his eventual wife, through to years of law practice and finally to his election as President and the Declaration of Independence. Cast also includes Gene Lockhart, Howard da Silva and Alan Baxter.

results.title: The Divorce of lady X
results.creator_credit: Tim Wheelan, Alexander Korda and United Artists Corporation
results.brief_description: This is a delightful and light romantic comedy starring Laurence Olivier and Merle Oberon. A thick fog in London forces those at a fancy dress ball to remain overnight at the hotel where the ball is being held. As there is a room shortage the charming and lovely Leslie Steel (Oberon) is forced to share a room with the irritable and handsome lawyer Evarard Logan (Olivier). The lawyer assumes that the mysterious and yet unnamed character is married. The following day an accusing Lord Mee (Ralph Richardson) talks of his wife spending the night in a man’s room. Smitten and bewildered Everard Logan is forced to think of the consequences believing that he might know the clients of a divorce case that he is working on better than he thought! This easy going yet sophisticated comedy is well performed and enjoyable.
